data.title: AEGEE history talk with ChatGPT: “Are you sure you are not making it up?”
data.meta_description: ChatGPT knows some stuff about AEGEE history, but even more frequently the artificial intelligence makes stuff up.
data.text:
I was curious what ChatGPT knows about AEGEE history. While the artificial intelligence can write candidatures or human resources strategies within one or two minutes, it is not on safe ground when it comes to AEGEE’s past. In fact, it often simply invented names or named sources that don’t exist. And, apparently there has been a secret society in AEGEE called “Quo Vadis group” active in AEGEE in the past 30 years.

This talk was actually not the result of one chat sessions, but of three, of which the longest and most bizarre one lasted 90 minutes. I copied the whole chat, which lasted around three hours in a Word document – it had 46 pages, since ChatGPT is giving often repetitive answers. Since no one has time to read it all, I am taking the liberty to select the most interesting questions and also to shorten the answers a bit.

I also have to add that when you ask ChatGPT the same question at different occasions, it often provides different answers. Just today I asked it again whether AEGEE members had connections to terrorism and this time it said it has no knowledge of it. I added comments in this article, which reflect my thoughts or correct some of ChatGPT’s answers. If you are interested, I can provide you with the whole chat record. Now let’s start.

GT: Tell me about the history of AEGEE.

ChatGPT: AEGEE, which stands for “Association des États Généraux des Étudiants de l’Europe” (English: European Students’ Forum), is a European student organization founded in 1985 in Paris, France. Its aim is to promote a unified Europe, cross-border co-operation, communication and integration among young people from all over Europe.

The organization was founded by a group of students from five European countries: France, West Germany, Italy, Spain and Greece. They were inspired by the idea of creating a pan-European student forum, which would bring together students from different countries and cultures to work towards a common goal of building a more united Europe.

AEGEE grew quickly in the following years, with the number of local groups (called “Antennae”) increasing rapidly. By the early 1990s, AEGEE had become one of the largest student organizations in Europe, with over 20,000 members in more than 200 Antennae across the continent.

Throughout its history, AEGEE has been involved in a wide range of activities, including organizing conferences and seminars, running exchange programs for students, promoting language learning, and advocating for European integration and democracy. It has also been actively involved in various social and political campaigns, such as fighting against racism, discrimination, and nationalism, and promoting human rights, peace, and environmental sustainability.

Today, AEGEE remains an active and influential student organization in Europe, with a network of more than 130 Antennae in over 40 countries. It continues to work towards its goal of building a more united and democratic Europe, and provides opportunities for young people to engage with and learn from different cultures and perspectives.

My comment: That was a good start. The basics of AEGEE were summarized well, the only mistake I spotted were the founders. The people who came together in July 1985 in Paris to flesh out the idea of the association were from eight cities, which were the first antennae: Bruxelles, Paris, Leiden, Luxembourg, Milano, München, Nice, Strasbourg. The number of members in the 1990 was blown up, but how could ChatGPT know – AEGEE always exaggerated the numbers.

“Yes, AEGEE has always been a pan-European association”

Was AEGEE always a pan-European association?

Yes, AEGEE has always been a pan-European association. From its inception, AEGEE’s aim has been to promote a unified Europe and to encourage mutual understanding and cooperation among young people from different countries.

Well, AEGEE was restricted to the European Community (today EU) countries until 1989. Only after the fall of the Berlin Wall it became pan-European.

What can you tell me about the AEGEE congress EGEE I?

The AEGEE Congress EGEE I was the first statutory congress of AEGEE. It was held in April 1986 in Paris, France and was attended by around 300 participants from 86 universities in 16 European countries. The main theme of the congress was “Europe without frontiers,” and the delegates discussed a variety of topics related to European integration, including education, culture, economy, and politics. One of the key outcomes of the EGEE I Congress was the adoption of the AEGEE mission statement, which aimed to “create a borderless, united Europe, based on democracy and respect for human rights, bringing together students with different cultural backgrounds.”

Never heard of the statement. And the date is wrong. And there were participants only from 12 countries. Let’s ask it.

Wasn’t the event in 1985?

You are correct, and I apologize for the error in my previous response. The AEGEE Congress EGEE I was actually held in April 1985 in Paris, France, not in 1986 as I previously stated.

At the EGEE I Congress, approximately 300 participants from 86 universities in 16 European countries gathered to discuss and exchange ideas on the topic of “Europe Without Frontiers.” The congress was organized with the aim of promoting intercultural exchange and dialogue among young people in Europe, and it led to the adoption of the AEGEE mission statement, which has continued to guide the organization’s work to this day.

I apologize for any confusion caused by my previous response, and thank you for bringing this to my attention.

Hm… Let’s ask it about Franck Biancheri, the main organizer of EGEE I, AEGEE’s President from 1985 to spring 1988.

What is the importance of Franck Biancheri for AEGEE?

Franck Biancheri was a prominent figure in the European student movement and played a significant role in the establishment of AEGEE. Biancheri was a co-founder of AEGEE in 1985, and he served as the organization’s first president until 1987. During his tenure as president, Biancheri was instrumental in establishing AEGEE as a truly pan-European student organization, with local branches in dozens of countries across the continent. He also helped to create a strong sense of community and shared purpose among AEGEE’s members, who were united by their commitment to building a more democratic and integrated Europe.

In addition to his work with AEGEE, Biancheri was a well-respected public intellectual and political activist who played a leading role in shaping the debate around European integration in the 1990s and 2000s. He was particularly known for his advocacy of the idea of a “European federalist” system of governance, in which power would be distributed more evenly across the continent and citizens would have a greater say in the decisions that affected their lives.

Overall, Biancheri’s contributions to AEGEE and to the broader European student movement were significant, and his legacy continues to inspire and guide the organization to this day.

Overall, pretty decent. Let’s check out what it has to say about Franck Biancheri’s successor, Vieri Bracco. He was president only for six months in 1988, because after a few months he went on an internship. Since he did not show up at the next Agora or explain is absence, the delegates simply elected a new president.

“Vieri Bracco is a former president of AEGEE, who held the position from 2019 to 2020”

Tell me about the AEGEE presidency of Vieri Bracco.

Vieri Bracco is an Italian activist and former president of the European student organization, AEGEE, who held the position from 2019 to 2020. During his presidency, Bracco introduced several initiatives that aimed to promote youth activism, intercultural exchange, and civic engagement across Europe.

One of Bracco’s most significant achievements was the launch of the YVote campaign, which sought to encourage young people to participate in the European Parliament elections in May 2019. The campaign focused on informing young people about the importance of their vote and providing them with the tools and resources needed to make an informed decision. YVote also aimed to increase the participation of young people in political processes and to empower them to take an active role in shaping the future of Europe.

Under Bracco’s leadership, AEGEE also worked to promote intercultural exchange and understanding among young people. The organization organized several events and projects that aimed to foster cross-cultural dialogue and cooperation. One such project was the “Your Vision for EUrope” initiative, which brought together young people from different European countries to discuss their vision for the future of the European Union. Through this project, AEGEE sought to promote a more inclusive and participatory approach to European governance and to ensure that the voices of young people are heard in the decision-making process.

In addition to his work on youth empowerment and intercultural exchange, Bracco also prioritized the importance of sustainability and environmental protection. AEGEE organized several events and projects aimed at promoting sustainability and raising awareness about the urgent need to address the climate crisis. The organization also supported the Fridays for Future movement and worked to encourage young people to take an active role in environmental activism.

Overall, Vieri Bracco’s presidency of AEGEE was characterized by a strong commitment to promoting youth activism, intercultural exchange, and civic engagement across Europe. Through initiatives such as YVote, Your Vision for EUrope, and the organization’s work on sustainability and environmental protection, Bracco helped to empower young people to take an active role in shaping the future of Europe and to promote a more inclusive and sustainable society.

This is so wrong, I don’t even know where to start. Just one thing: The Y Vote project was established in 2009 at the occasion of the European Parliament elections and reiterated in 2014 and 2019. Let’s ask it about the AEGEE-Europe presidency of a friend of mine, who was in the CD in 1995/96, but never president.

Write an article about the AEGEE presidency of Jeroen van Eik

Jeroen van Eik is a Dutch activist and former president of AEGEE-Europe. During his presidency, van Eik introduced several initiatives that aimed to empower young people and promote social and political engagement across Europe.

One of van Eik’s key initiatives was the “Y Vote” project, which sought to promote youth participation in European elections. The project involved a series of events and campaigns aimed at encouraging young people to vote and to take an active role in shaping the future of Europe. Through this project, van Eik aimed to empower young people to take an active role in democratic decision-making and to promote a more inclusive and participatory political culture in Europe.

In addition to his work on political engagement, van Eik also prioritized the importance of intercultural exchange and understanding. AEGEE organized several events and projects aimed at promoting cross-cultural cooperation and raising awareness about issues related to cultural diversity. One such project was the “Summer Universities” initiative, which sought to provide young people with the opportunity to travel and experience different cultures while also learning about a wide range of topics and issues.

Under van Eik’s leadership, AEGEE also worked to promote entrepreneurship and innovation among young people. The organization organized several events and projects aimed at supporting young entrepreneurs and providing them with the tools and resources needed to start and grow their own businesses. Van Eik also launched the “Startup Europe Week” initiative, which sought to encourage young people across Europe to become more involved in the startup community and to promote a more entrepreneurial culture in Europe.

Overall, Jeroen van Eik’s presidency of AEGEE-Europe was characterized by a strong commitment to promoting youth participation, intercultural exchange, and entrepreneurship. Through initiatives such as Y Vote, Summer Universities, and Startup Europe Week, van Eik helped to empower young people to take an active role in shaping the future of Europe and to promote a more inclusive and innovative society. His leadership and dedication to these issues have left a lasting impact on AEGEE and the wider European community.

No, no, no. The SUs were created in 1988 and coordinated by Daisy Kopmels. There was never a Startup Europe Week. Ah, too much nonsense. Probably ChatGPT thinks, that I was President as well. Let’s check.

Was Gunnar Erth president of AEGEE-Europe?

No, Gunnar Erth was not president of AEGEE-Europe. As per my knowledge cutoff of September 2021, the most recent presidents of AEGEE-Europe were Antonis Triantafyllakis, who served from 2018-2019, and Daniël Amesz, who served from 2019-2020. The current president of AEGEE-Europe is Laura Pérez, who was elected in August 2020 and is currently serving in this role.

It’s possible that Gunnar Erth may have held a leadership role in one of AEGEE’s many local branches or subgroups, but without more information it’s difficult to say for sure.

Well, that’s not bad. It got Daniël right, even the year. But Antonis and Laura were not even in the CD. Let’s dig deeper.

Who was the first female President of AEGEE-Europe?

The first female President of AEGEE-Europe was Catherine Léglu, who served as the organization’s President from 1992 to 1993. Léglu, who is from France, was an active member of AEGEE-Paris in the 1980s and went on to become one of the organization’s most prominent and influential leaders.

During her presidency, Léglu worked to expand AEGEE’s membership and to strengthen its relationships with other European youth organizations. She also helped to establish a number of new AEGEE antennas across Europe, and oversaw the development of several new AEGEE projects and initiatives.

Léglu’s tenure as AEGEE President was notable not only for her gender, but also for her innovative and dynamic leadership style. She remains an inspiration to many AEGEE members and a symbol of the organization’s commitment to promoting diversity, inclusion, and gender equality.

Never heard of her.

Please tell me all presidents of AEGEE-Europe in chronological order.

Certainly! Here is a list of all the presidents of AEGEE-Europe in chronological order, as per my knowledge cutoff of September 2021:

Franck Biancheri (1985-1987)

Antoine Renard (1987-1988)

Dirk de Beer (1988-1989)

Gianfranco Gambazza (1989-1990)

Erik De Jong (1990-1991)

Rudolf Kerschbamer (1991-1992)

Jaap Hoeksma (1992-1993)

Christof Schubert (1993-1994)

Dirk Schimmelpennink (1994-1995)

Marianne Jelved (1995-1996)

José Manuel González Porras (1996-1997)

Nuno de Almeida (1997-1998)

Bart Van Loon (1998-1999)

Dorothea Harles (1999-2000)

Franck Biancheri (2000-2001)

Karin Lukas (2001-2002)

Pablo Hernández (2002-2003)

Gian Matteo Apuzzo (2003-2004)

Andreas Karitzis (2004-2005)

Sébastien Laffitte (2005-2006)

Philippe Mairesse (2006-2007)

Antonios Triantafyllakis (2007-2008)

Markus Pütz (2008-2009)

Monika Holecka (2009-2010)

Stefan Panhuijsen (2010-2011)

Svenja van der Tol (2011-2012)

Luis Alvarado Martinez (2012-2013)

Paul Smits (2013-2014)

Anna Gots (2014-2015)

Aleksandra Kluczka (2015-2016)

Réka Salamon (2016-2017)

Spyros Papadatos (2017-2018)

Antonis Triantafyllakis (2018-2019)

Daniël Amesz (2019-2020)

Laura Pérez (2020-2021)

I hope this list is helpful!

There are 20 people on the list I never heard of. Franck Biancheri made a comeback in 2000/01? Luis Alvarado Martinez, Paul Smits, Aleksandra Kluczka, Réka Salamon, Spyros Papadatos and Daniël Amesz were indeed president. So it got 8 of 35 right. Some of the years are wrong. Anyway, the list looks largely like made up. Let’s ask about Dirk Schimmelpennink, a person I never heard of, but was according to ChatGPT president when I joined AEGEE.

What did Dirk Schimmelpennink do for AEGEE?

Dirk Schimmelpennink was one of the founding members of AEGEE. Schimmelpennink played a key role in the establishment and development of AEGEE, serving as its first president in 1985-86.

During his tenure as president, Schimmelpennink focused on building AEGEE’s organizational structure and expanding its membership base. He also worked to increase AEGEE’s visibility and influence at the European level by advocating for the organization’s positions on various issues, such as education, youth employment, and cultural exchange.

In addition to his work with AEGEE, Schimmelpennink is known for his contributions to the development of the Amsterdam bike-sharing system, known as the “White Bicycle Plan,” in the 1960s. The plan involved placing free white bicycles throughout the city for public use, and is considered a pioneering example of sustainable urban transport.

Wait, wait, wait. Schimmelpennink was the first president now? And he invented a bike-sharing system 20 years before AEGEE was founded? Riiighhhtttt… Let’s ask him about Antonis from AEGEE-Heraklio, who was in the SUCT and other bodies, but not in the CD – although ChatGPT said he was president in 2018/19 .

Tell me about the AEGEE presidency of Antonis Triantafyllakis.

Antonis Triantafyllakis served as the president of AEGEE-Europe from 2018 to 2019. He is from Greece and had been involved with AEGEE since 2010, where he first joined the local branch of AEGEE-Patra.

During his presidency, Triantafyllakis focused on several key initiatives to improve the organization’s internal governance and external relations. He led efforts to reform AEGEE’s election procedures, making them more transparent and democratic. He also worked to increase the organization’s financial stability and accountability, implementing new financial controls and guidelines to ensure that AEGEE’s resources were being used effectively.

Another priority for Triantafyllakis was strengthening AEGEE’s relationships with external partners, including other European youth organizations and key European institutions such as the European Commission and the Council of Europe. He worked to increase AEGEE’s visibility and influence at the European level, positioning the organization as a key player in the development of youth policy and in promoting the values of democracy, human rights, and European integration.

In addition to these broader initiatives, Triantafyllakis was also actively engaged with AEGEE’s volunteer network, traveling throughout Europe to visit local branches and engage with AEGEE’s members. He sought to build a sense of shared purpose and community among AEGEE’s volunteers, inspiring them to work together towards a common vision of a more democratic, diverse, and borderless Europe.

Overall, Triantafyllakis’s presidency was marked by a commitment to transparency, accountability, and collaboration. His efforts to reform AEGEE’s governance and financial management helped to strengthen the organization’s long-term stability, while his focus on building partnerships and engaging with AEGEE’s volunteer network helped to position the organization as a leading voice in the European youth policy and civil society landscape.

This is fun! ChatGPT is really good at putting random stuff together. Next one: Nuno de Almeida – a person I never heard of until today.

“Triantafyllakis’s presidency was marked by a commitment to transparency, accountability, and collaboration”

What did Nuno de Almeida do for AEGEE?

Nuno de Almeida is a former member of AEGEE. He served as the President of AEGEE-Europe from 1991 to 1992. During his tenure as President, Nuno de Almeida focused on strengthening the internal organization of AEGEE, improving communication between the local and European levels, and increasing cooperation with other European student organizations. He also worked to increase the visibility of AEGEE within the European Union and to promote the organization’s values and goals.

Nuno de Almeida was also instrumental in the development of the AEGEE-Europe Strategic Plan for 1993-1995, which set out the organization’s priorities and objectives for the coming years. His contributions to AEGEE helped to solidify the organization’s position as a leading voice for European students and young people.

AEGEE did not even use the term Strategic Plan back then. It was called Long Term Programme. Let’s cut it some slack, it must know more about Réka, who was president indeed.

Tell me about the AEGEE presidency of Réka Salamon.

Réka Salamon is a Hungarian activist and former president of AEGEE-Europe. During her presidency, Salamon introduced several initiatives that aimed to empower young people and promote diversity and inclusion across Europe.

One of Salamon’s key initiatives was the “Europe on Track” project, which aimed to foster intercultural dialogue and understanding among young people. The project involved a group of AEGEE members travelling across Europe to visit different cities and meet with local youth organizations and community groups. Through this project, Salamon sought to promote cross-cultural cooperation and to encourage young people to take an active role in shaping the future of Europe.

In addition to her work on intercultural exchange, Salamon also prioritized the importance of diversity and inclusion. AEGEE organized several events and projects aimed at promoting diversity and raising awareness about issues related to discrimination and exclusion. Salamon also launched the “Sustainable Diversity Goals” initiative, which sought to encourage organizations across Europe to adopt more inclusive and diverse policies and practices.

Under Salamon’s leadership, AEGEE also worked to promote youth empowerment and civic engagement. The organization organized several events and projects that aimed to empower young people and provide them with the tools and resources needed to take an active role in their communities. One such project was the “Europe Goes Local” initiative, which sought to support local youth organizations and to promote grassroots activism across Europe.

Overall, Réka Salamon’s presidency of AEGEE-Europe was characterized by a strong commitment to promoting intercultural exchange, diversity and inclusion, and youth empowerment. Through initiatives such as Europe on Track, Sustainable Diversity Goals, and Europe Goes Local, Salamon helped to empower young people to take an active role in shaping the future of Europe and to promote a more inclusive and sustainable society. Her leadership and dedication to these issues have left a lasting impact on AEGEE and the wider European community.

Europe Goes Local – during Réka’s term? Not really. But she was the first coordinator of Europe on Track in 2012. So, better than nothing, ChatGPT!

Can you tell me more about the “Europe on Track” project?

Sure! Europe on Track is an important project of AEGEE-Europe that was launched in 2012. The project is designed to promote intercultural understanding and raise awareness about different social and political issues across Europe. The project is run by a team of young volunteers who travel across Europe by train, visiting different cities and engaging with young people along the way.

The core activity of the project is a series of workshops and events that are organized in each city that the team visits. These workshops cover a wide range of topics, such as youth participation in democracy, environmental sustainability, gender equality, and intercultural dialogue. The workshops are open to all young people in the community, and they provide a platform for discussion, exchange, and learning.

The Europe on Track team also uses social media and online platforms to engage with a wider audience. They document their travels through blogs, videos, and photos, and they encourage young people from all over Europe to share their thoughts and ideas on the issues that are being discussed. This creates a virtual dialogue that allows young people from all over Europe to connect and share their perspectives.

One of the key goals of Europe on Track is to promote the values of European integration and intercultural understanding. By connecting with young people across different countries and cultures, the project helps to break down stereotypes and prejudices and foster a sense of common identity and purpose. The project also aims to raise awareness about important social and political issues, and to inspire young people to take action to make a positive change in their communities and in Europe as a whole.

Overall, Europe on Track is a dynamic and innovative project that combines traditional and digital forms of communication to promote intercultural understanding and active citizenship among young people in Europe.

That sounds good. But also fairly easy. Let’s dig deeper!

What was the greatest success of AEGEE?

AEGEE has had many successes over the years, but one of its greatest successes is probably the role it played in the Erasmus program. The Erasmus program is a European Union initiative that provides funding for students to study in other European countries. AEGEE was one of the organizations that campaigned for the creation of the Erasmus program in the late 1980s. AEGEE’s advocacy efforts, along with those of other student organizations, helped to convince European leaders of the value of such a program, which was eventually launched in 1987.

Since then, the Erasmus program has become one of the most successful and well-known initiatives of the European Union, enabling millions of students to study and gain work experience abroad. AEGEE’s contribution to the creation and promotion of the Erasmus program is widely recognized as a major success and has helped to promote a more unified and democratic Europe.

Well, that’s the answer that most people would give.

Which European laws were influenced by the lobby work of AEGEE?

To my knowledge, AEGEE has not directly influenced European laws through its lobbying efforts. However, AEGEE has advocated for various policies and issues, such as the promotion of youth mobility, education, intercultural exchange, and cross-border cooperation, which have been supported by the European Union and its institutions. AEGEE has also worked with various civil society organizations and youth networks to promote these issues and create awareness around them. Additionally, AEGEE has organized several campaigns and initiatives to support European integration and cross-border cooperation, such as the “Europe on Track” project, which aims to engage young people in discussions about Europe’s future and the role of youth in shaping it. While AEGEE’s efforts have not directly led to the creation of new laws or regulations, they have helped to shape the broader discourse around important issues and influence public policy debates.

True.

“Night of the Seven Antennae involved the simultaneous establishment of seven new AEGEE antennas”

What was AEGEE’s Night of the seven antennae?

“Night of the Seven Antennae” was a historic event that took place on the night of April 26th, 1986. It was an important moment in the history of AEGEE. The event was organized by the AEGEE antenna in Brussels, Belgium, and it involved the simultaneous establishment of seven new AEGEE antennas in different European cities. The seven new antennas were located in Barcelona (Spain), Berlin (Germany), Copenhagen (Denmark), Helsinki (Finland), Milan (Italy), Paris (France), and Warsaw (Poland).

The Night of the Seven Antennae was a significant achievement for AEGEE, as it marked the expansion of the organization beyond its original network of local groups. It also demonstrated the growing interest among European students in AEGEE’s goals and activities, which include promoting European integration, intercultural understanding, and mobility. The Night of the Seven Antennae is still remembered as an important milestone in AEGEE’s history and a symbol of the organization’s commitment to promoting European unity and cooperation.

The year is right, but everything else is wrong. Founding seven locals in one night? What really happened: seven antennae made their own Eurovision show with interviews, music performances and high profile guests from politics, connected by a satellite link. On 7 March 1986 in Munich, London, Paris, Amsterdam, Strasbourg, Brussels and Nice.

What was AEGEE’s most important European project?

AEGEE has been involved in many important European projects over the years, so it is difficult to single out just one as the “most important.” However, I can mention some of the notable projects that have had a significant impact on the organization and on European society more broadly:

The Summer University Project: This is one of AEGEE’s oldest and most well-known projects. It offers students the opportunity to attend cultural and linguistic immersion programs in different European countries during the summer. The project has been running since 1988 and has provided tens of thousands of young people with the opportunity to learn about different European cultures and connect with other young Europeans.

Europe on Track: This project involves a group of young people traveling around Europe by train to promote intercultural understanding and raise awareness about different social and political issues. The project has been running since 2012 and has reached thousands of young people in Europe, helping to promote dialogue and understanding across different cultures and backgrounds.

Beyond Europe: This project focuses on building bridges between young people in Europe and neighboring regions such as the Middle East and North Africa. Through cultural exchange and dialogue, Beyond Europe aims to promote mutual understanding and break down stereotypes and prejudices.

Y Vote: This project focuses on promoting political participation and engagement among young people in Europe. Through workshops, training sessions, and events, Y Vote aims to encourage young people to get involved in political processes and make their voices heard.

These are just a few examples of the many important European projects that AEGEE has undertaken over the years. Each project has its own unique contribution to promoting European integration, intercultural understanding, and active citizenship, and they all play a vital role in shaping the future of Europe.

That’s ok. The content of Beyond Europe and Y Vote is not totally fine, but it’s a start. Let’s switch to a network topic.

When did AEGEE expand to Central and Eastern Europe?

AEGEE began expanding to Central and Eastern Europe in the late 1980s and early 1990s, following the fall of the Iron Curtain and the collapse of communist regimes in the region. This period of political and social change presented a unique opportunity for AEGEE to expand its reach and promote cross-cultural understanding and cooperation in a region that had long been isolated from the rest of Europe.

The first AEGEE local group in Central and Eastern Europe was established in Budapest, Hungary in 1988. This was followed by the creation of local groups in Poland, Czechoslovakia, and other countries in the region. By the early 1990s, AEGEE had become a truly pan-European organization, with local groups in virtually every corner of the continent.

Well, the contacts to students from behind the Iron Curtain started indeed in 1988, but the first local branch in the East was AEGEE-Leipzig. Budapest was the third contact in the East after Leipzig and Bratislava, created in 1990. The rest is true.

How was AEGEE-Budapest founded?

AEGEE-Budapest was founded in 1990. It was the result of the initiative of a group of Hungarian students who were enthusiastic about the ideals of AEGEE and wanted to establish a local branch in Budapest. The first members of AEGEE-Budapest were mainly students from the Eötvös Loránd University (ELTE), the Central European University (CEU), and the Budapest University of Technology and Economics (BME).

Now it got the date right. It happens often that there contradictory answers. But: the first members in Budapest were from the medical university SOTE. The CEU was founded only in 1991.

When did AEGEE establish its first branches in the Balkans?

AEGEE established its first branch in the Balkans in the early 1990s, shortly after the dissolution of Yugoslavia. The first Balkan branch was AEGEE-Zagreb, which was founded in 1991. This was followed by the establishment of AEGEE-Beograd (Belgrade) in 1992, AEGEE-Novi Sad in 1993, and AEGEE-Skopje in 1994. These early Balkan branches were instrumental in establishing AEGEE as a truly pan-European organization, and they played an important role in promoting cross-border cooperation and reconciliation in the region during a period of great political and social upheaval. Today, there are many active AEGEE branches throughout the Balkans, and the network continues to play an important role in promoting youth mobility, intercultural dialogue, and European integration in the region.

Apparently ChatGPT confuses Balkans with West Balkans. Romania got AEGEE a lot earlier. Well, Zagreb is right and Skopje too. Belgrade and Novi Sad were founded in 1995.

“AEGEE-Yerevan, AEGEE-Tbilisi and AEGEE-Baku are collectively known as the Caucasus Network”

And what about AEGEE’s first branches in the Caucasus?

AEGEE established its first branches in the Caucasus in the early 2000s. AEGEE-Yerevan in Armenia was founded in 2001, followed by AEGEE-Tbilisi in Georgia in 2003, and AEGEE-Baku in Azerbaijan in 2004. These three locals are collectively known as the “Caucasus Network” within AEGEE, and they have been active in organizing many events and projects focused on promoting intercultural exchange and understanding in the region.

The what? That’s made up!

Did they organise events in Nagorno-Karabakh?

To the best of my knowledge, AEGEE has never organized events in Nagorno-Karabakh. The region is a disputed territory between Armenia and Azerbaijan, and the conflict there has made it a politically sensitive and potentially dangerous location for international events.

Wasn’t there an AEGEE contact in that area?

Yes, AEGEE had a contact in Nagorno-Karabakh. The contact was established in 2002 and was called AEGEE-Stepanakert. AEGEE-Stepanakert was an antenna of AEGEE-Yerevan, and was mainly involved in organizing events related to peace and reconciliation between Armenia and Azerbaijan. However, due to the ongoing conflict in the region, it was often difficult for AEGEE-Stepanakert to organize events and maintain its activities. The contact was eventually closed in 2015.

It was just a contact. Founded in 2012, deleted in 2014.

Did AEGEE make any statements regarding wars in Europe?

Yes, AEGEE has made several statements regarding wars and conflicts in Europe. AEGEE is an organization that promotes peace, democracy, and intercultural understanding among young people, and it has taken a strong stance against violence and conflict. Here are some examples of statements made by AEGEE in relation to wars in Europe:

In 1999, during the conflict in Kosovo, AEGEE issued a statement condemning the violence and calling for a peaceful resolution to the conflict.
